title.narrative: Denmark’s contribution to the United Nations Indigenous Fellowship Programme 2020-2021

description.narrative: The Indigenous Fellowship Programme (IFP) is a comprehensive human rights training programme that was established by the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) in the context of the first International Decade of the World's Indigenous Peoples (1995-2004). The programme aims to build the capacity and expertise of indigenous representatives on the UN human rights system and mechanisms dealing with human rights in general and indigenous issues in particular, so they are in a better position to protect and promote the rights of their communities. The IFP is held annually and fellows from the programme are trained together during 4 to 5 weeks in Geneva. The date of the training programme usually coincides with the annual meeting of the UN Expert Mechanism on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, thus allowing the fellows to participate more actively in international advocacy while participating in the Programme. In 2020, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the annual Fellowship Programme held in Geneva was cancelled and redesigned into a country-based programme with former Fellows posted as “Senior Fellows” in OHCHR country and regional offices, UN Country Teams (UNCTs) or UN Peacekeeping Operations.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (extrabudgetary contributions only)

title.narrative: Application of concrete knowledge learned by Indigenous Fellows resulting in the enhanced use of knowledge about UN normative framework and UN human rights mechanisms in relation to programme implementation.
Number of months of experience spent in a OHCHR or other UN operation at country level implementing an agreed workplan.

target.value: Annual target: 20 Senior Indigenous Fellows are able to apply knowledge in their work about the UN normative framework and UN human rights mechanisms.
Annual target: 20 Senior Indigenous Fellows are able to apply knowledge in their work about the UN normative framework and UN human rights mechanisms.

title.narrative: Provision by Senior Indigenous Fellows of thematic guidance to OHCHR and UN operations on the ground resulting in improved quality of UN interventions and impact.
Number of UN projects Senior Indigenous Fellows are involved in.

target.value: Annual target: 20 Senior Indigenous Fellows provide thematic lead and guidance to OHCHR or UN offices, including in relation to COVID-19 projects.
Annual target: 20 Senior Indigenous Fellows provide thematic lead and guidance to OHCHR or UN offices, including in relation to COVID-19 projects.

title.narrative: Senior Indigenous Fellows are trained on the job (short term) and empowered to act as leaders to advocate for their rights locally and internationally (medium term).
Senior Indigenous Fellows are trained and empowered.

target.value: 20 Senior Indigenous Fellows are supported in country or regional UN offices in 16 locations covering all regions: Africa (Democratic Republic of Congo, Cameroon, Chad, Ethiopia, Kenya, Senegal); Pacific (Fiji); Latin and Central America (Chile-regional office for Latin America; Brazil (2), Colombia (3), Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Guatemala); Asia (Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia).

title.narrative: Senior Indigenous Fellows have enhanced their advocacy and leadership knowledge and skills.
Senior Indigenous Fellows after their work for the UN engage locally and internationally in activities to advocate for their rights.

target.value: Annual target: Former Senior Indigenous Fellows advocate for their rights in an impactful manner.
Annual target: Former Senior Indigenous Fellows advocate for their rights in an impactful manner.
